author: Ray Faure
title: Rand recoups some losses but remains fragile | Markets
text:
THE rand managed to recoup some of its earlier losses in late afternoon trade on Monday, but remained fragile as commodity-based currencies laboured under concerns over a slowdown in China’s economy.
Commodity-based currencies, including the rand, weakened sharply on Friday as the People’s Bank of China cut benchmark rates and banks’ reserve requirement to support the faltering Chinese economy, Barclays said in a note on Monday.
"Indeed, China’s stimulus measures heightened fears of a slowdown in the world’s second-largest economy, much to the detriment of its trading partners such as SA. The rand fell 1.81% versus the dollar, 1.53% against the pound and 0.99% versus the euro, and was the worst-performing currency among its emerging-market peers," Barclays said.
At 3.50pm the rand was at R13.5777 against the dollar from its previous close of R13.6437.
The local currency was at R14.9561 against the euro from R15.0157 and at R20.8214 against the pound from a previous close of R20.8805.
The euro was at $1.1015 from a previous close of $1.1008.
The focus of global markets this week is Wednesday’s US Federal Reserve interest rate decision. Market consensus is that rates will be kept on hold.
